item.title: Britain Receives Proposals for ‘Better Deal’ on E.U. Membership
item.description: A package of concessions intended to encourage Britons to stay in the bloc has been announced, potentially clearing the way to a referendum.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, right, and Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, at Downing Street in London on Sunday.

item.title: Sinosphere: Video Extols China’s Party Slogans, Turning to Rap and Beethoven
item.description: A cartoon video released by Xinhua, the state news agency, praises priorities that President Xi Jinping laid out in December 2014.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO and PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: John Kerry Urges Coalition to Address Growing ISIS Threat in Libya
item.description: The secretary of state said the formation of a national unity government would prevent the Islamic State from seizing control of the country.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, center, on Tuesday at the anti-Islamic State coalition meeting in Rome.

item.title: Sinosphere: Exalting Life as a Single in China
item.description: The social pressure to marry is so great, particularly during the Lunar New Year, that a group paid for an ad to go up on Thursday at a subway station in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A staged mass wedding in Shanghai, part of a matchmaking event to inspire singles to marry. Young Chinese can feel enormous pressure from their families to settle down, especially when relatives assemble for the Lunar New Year.

item.title: Benoît Violier’s Death Shines Light on High-Pressure Restaurant World
item.description: Mr. Violier ran the Restaurant de l’Hôtel de Ville in Switzerland, which was named the world’s best in December. The police said his death appeared to have been a suicide.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and KIM SEVERSON
item.media:description: Benoît Violier in 2013. The French-Swiss chef was found dead on Sunday at his home in Crissier, near Lausanne, Switzerland.

item.title: Britain Awaits Proposals for ‘Better Deal’ on E.U. Membership
item.description: A package of concessions intended to encourage Britons to stay in the bloc is expected to be announced on Tuesday, potentially clearing the way to a referendum.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, right, and Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, at Downing Street in London on Sunday.

item.title: World Briefing: Ivory Coast: Gbago Was a Defender of Democracy, Lawyer Tells Court
item.description: A defense lawyer made the argument in his opening statement at Laurent Gbagbo’s trial on charges of crimes against humanity.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Castro Finds Advocates in Paris
item.description: The French government urged the United States to lift the economic embargo against Cuba during a state visit by the Cuban president, Raúl Castro.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Boko Haram Raid in Nigeria Kills at Least 65
item.description: Militants descended Saturday evening on the small village of Dalori, where they unleashed a torrent of gunfire, set homes ablaze, blew up fleeing residents and abducted children.
item.dc:creator: ILIYA KURE and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: The wreckage of Dalori village, Nigeria. The militants set fire to as many as 300 homes in the village, burning some people alive.

item.title: U.S. Fortifying Europe’s East to Deter Putin
item.description: President Obama plans to increase the deployment of heavy weapons and other equipment to NATO countries in Central and Eastern Europe.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and HELENE COOPER
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lithuanian soldiers inspected a United States Army Stryker vehicle last year during an exercise. Lithuania and its Baltic neighbors, Estonia and Latvia, are among the NATO countries that have been asking for a statement of American military support.

item.title: Zika Virus a Global Health Emergency, W.H.O. Says
item.description: In its decision, the World Health Organization highlighted the seriousness of the Zika outbreak, a mosquito-borne virus thought to cause birth defects that has exploded in Latin America, and gave countries powerful tools to fight it.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE and DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: A worker conducting fumigation as a preventive measure against the Zika virus at a cemetery on the outskirts of Lima, Peru.

item.title: Syria Talks Are Declared Open as Mediator Begins Shuttle Diplomacy
item.description: There have been no direct talks between the sides, but the United Nations mediator said he considered the negotiations officially started because he had conferred with each delegation.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Staffan de Mistura, second from left, the United Nations mediator in the Syria war, sat opposite Syria’s main opposition group during peace talks on Monday in Geneva.

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Khomeini’s Grandson Receives an Endorsement After Disqualification
item.description: Hassan Khomeini said he would appeal his disqualification to run for a seat on the council, which is empowered to choose the next supreme leader.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: India: 13 Swimmers Drown in Riptide
item.description: The bodies of 10 women and three men were recovered, and one student was still missing.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Menacing Video Posted by Chechen Leader Alarms Critics of Putin in Russia
item.description: The video, which appeared to show a Russian opposition figure in the cross hairs of a sniper’s rifle, was removed from Instagram because it violated guidelines against threats or harassment, a spokeswoman said.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A post on the Instagram account of Ramzon Kadyrov appeared to show a Russian opposition politician in the cross hairs.

item.title: Economists Sharply Split Over Trade Deal Effects
item.description: It may be a political football for presidential candidates, but the liveliest debate recently about the Trans-Pacific Partnership is among blue-ribbon economists.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES
item.media:description: Protestors waving placards at a rally opposing the Trans-Pacific Partnership in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, last month.

item.title: Take a Number: Reverberations From a Rise in Mexico’s Murder Rate
item.description: Rising homicide rates are lowering a country’s average life expectancy.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER

item.title: Australia to Begin Monitoring for Zika Virus
item.description: Health officials in the northern part of Queensland and Papua New Guinea, to Australia’s north, have begun taking measures to guard against the virus.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Terror Threats Thaw Budgets Across Europe
item.description: Europe is greatly increasing military and security spending on the fight against terrorism, a shift from the austerity mantra that has dominated its policies in recent years.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolling near the Eiffel Tower.

item.title: First Freely Elected Parliament After Decades of Military Rule Opens in Myanmar
item.description: More than 100 of the new lawmakers are, like the democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, former political prisoners.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of Myanmar’s democracy movement, arrived for the opening session of the lower house of Parliament in Naypyidaw, the capital, on Monday.
